thread.title: Why United Airlines executives were so elated Monday afternoon
thread.title_full: Why United Airlines executives were so elated Monday afternoon

author: Lewis Lazare
title: Why United Airlines executives were so elated Monday afternoon
text:
Why United Airlines executives were so elated Monday afternoon Jul 21, 2015, 12:18pm CDT Share Monday was potentially a very good day for United Airlines CEO Jeff Smisek and theâ€¦ more Folks at United Airlines were super excited Monday. So excited, in fact, they sent out a special statement yesterday afternoon congratulating both the United States and Cuban governments on Monday's historic reopening of their respective embassies in Washington, D.C. and Havana, Cuba. That significant diplomatic development marked a further warming of relations between two countries that had broken off ties more than 50 years ago. Now that President Barack Obama has said Cuba and the U.S. can be friends again, United (NYSE: UAL) is wasting no time suggesting that's just fine with the airline too. And don't be surprised if United rushes to start flights between the U.S. and Cuba just as soon as the necessary government approvals are in place. How long could that take? Probably a minimum of six months. But maybe longer. We've got 50-plus years of bad blood to deal with, remember. When United Airlines does launch regular service between the U.S. and Cuba, however, don't count on Chicago, United's hometown, being one of the lucky United hubs to get the first flights between the two countries. No, that honor is likely to go to Houston and New York City/Newark. A United spokesman indicated "we look forward to providing our customers service to Cuba from our global gateways in Newark and Houston." Subject, of course, to that aforementioned government approval.
